articles.title: Single Childcare Benefit Proposed
articles.text:
Single Childcare Benefit Proposed
 
The Federal Government should replace the existing patchwork of
childcare benefits and funding with a single, direct-paid and
means-tested benefit, a Government think tank said yesterday.



The Economic Planning Advisory Council released its final report
Future Child  Care Provision in Australia, supporting means-tested
childcare support and payments made direct to families via a
"smart-card" system.
 
It also recommended the abolition of the fringe benefits ...

articles.title: Women just can't win.
articles.text:
Women just can't win.
 
WOMEN began this century unable to vote and are finishing it seemingly unable to win.



We have, at least in the Western world, achieved legal protections and citizenship entitlements that would have been unthinkable to our great-grandmothers who could not vote, divorce, or own property (including any money they might have earned from employment) and were not the legal guardians of their own children.
 
And they had to wear corsets.



But rather than these reforms bein ...

articles.title: POLITICS STILL DRIVES HOME OWNERSHIP
articles.text:
POLITICS STILL DRIVES HOME OWNERSHIP THE great Australian dream of home ownership is becoming increasingly politicised.

Once an icon, and respected as such by political parties, home ownership and housing policy is becoming another political battleground in the lead-up to the next election. It's a risky business as the Governor-General, Mr Hayden, could testify.

In 1980, as leader of the Labor Opposition, he toyed with extending the capital gain tax to the family home.

It lost Labor the elect ...

articles.title: IDEALS FOR A SOCIALLY JUST LABOR PARTY
articles.text:
IDEALS FOR A SOCIALLY JUST LABOR PARTY
 
AS IS his wont, Bob Hawke laid it on too thick when he boasted last
week that the Government had achieved its goal of eliminating child
poverty.



According to the the Australian Institute of Family Studies, the
Government's family assistance measures will cut child poverty by 36 per
cent, or almost 50 per cent if you do not take into account increased
housing costs. That is a big cut but it still leaves about 200,000
families, including more than 400,0 ...

articles.title: HOW THE TAX CUTS AND CHANGES AFFECT YOU.
articles.text:
HOW THE TAX CUTS AND CHANGES AFFECT YOU.
 
The 24 tables below provide a detailed estimate of the impact of the new tax system on various types of households. They show how the increases in social security and family benefits, and the income tax cuts, will outweigh the likely impact of the changes on the cost of living.



* The new tax scale concentrates tax cuts on middle-income earners; those earning between $38,000 and $50,000 will find their marginal tax rate cut from 43 per cent to 30 per ...

articles.title: A More Responsive Welfare System
articles.text: A More Responsive Welfare System THE 65 recommendations in the welfare report commissioned by the Federal Government and released yesterday would, if adopted, represent a radical overhaul of Australia's welfare system. Welfare reform is often taken to be synonymous with welfare cuts. If the welfare budget is reduced because more people have jobs, and therefore the opportunity to participate meaningfully in society, that can only be a welcome development. But if a reduction comes about because of ...

articles.title: What Future For Public Housing?
articles.text:
What Future For Public Housing?
 
THE time is December 1980. Jeffrey Kennett has just been appointed
Minister for Housing in the Hamer Government. `The Age' is not
impressed. Mr Kennett has been selected over more able contenders, says
its editorial. He ``would seem to add little to a ministry which is
already short on intellectual talent and social concern. Let us hope we
have misjudged him''.



In fact Mr Kennett proved to be an enthusiastic housing minister,
taking on the Fraser Government  ...

articles.title: Lost Causes: A Little Home Comfort For The Battlers
articles.text:
Lost Causes: A Little Home Comfort For The Battlers
 
Families are usually the focus of the Government's rhetoric but this
Budget they hardly rate a mention.



You have to look long and hard to find any measures that will help
families. And you will look in vain for any relief from the high cost of
child care that has resulted from past Government budget cuts.
 
The Government has clearly decided the political fallout from the
child-care crisis is not serious enough to warrant even minimal
adj ...

articles.title: WINNERS AND SOME LOSERS
articles.text:
WINNERS AND SOME LOSERS
 
THE new home child carer's allowance, which starts at the end of this
month, will leave some families winners and some losers. Winners will
include families where the wife earns up to $500 a week for the first
six months of the year, then gives up work to have a baby.



Losers include couples where a wife has been able to deduct child care
and  transport from her separate net income so that her spouse can
qualify for the higher dependent spouse rebate for those with d ...

articles.title: WOMEN FEAR SETBACKS UNDER COALITION
articles.text:
WOMEN FEAR SETBACKS UNDER COALITION
 
A peak women's organisation and a group of professional women have
attacked the Coalition's stance on women, claiming its policies would be
seriously damaging to Australian women.



The Women's Electoral Lobby (WEL) claims the Government's policies on
health and child care go a step further than the Coalition's.
 
And Just Women, a group of about 100 mainly professional women,
launched an anti-GST attack in Sydney yesterday, claiming the Coalition
would se ...

articles.title: MIDDLE INCOME EARNERS DO BEST
articles.text:
MIDDLE INCOME EARNERS DO BEST
 
The Federal Government's July 1 tax cuts have incorporated increases
in family assistance, giving middle income families with children the
most to celebrate from the $4.9 billion package.



Families with two children on average weekly earnings of $26,000 will
receive a tax cut of $24 a week, equivalent to a $40-a-week wage rise.
Overall, families with children earning between $20,000 and $35,000 will
receive between $20 and $25 a week extra in after-tax income.
 ...

articles.title: Parents Seeking Care For Children To Benefit
articles.text:
Parents Seeking Care For Children To Benefit
 
Child care was one of the big winners in yesterday's federal Budget
with a  total increase in annual spending from $440 million to $537
million.



Working parents using long day child-care have been given a
$5.50-a-week boost to fee relief, taking the maximum subsidy available
per child to $93 a week.
 
The move will benefit 69,000 families now receiving full fee relief of
$4375 a year, by an additional $250 for each child in care, with
another 66 ...

articles.title: Libs Offer Families $200 Tax Relief For Each Child
articles.text:
Libs Offer Families $200 Tax Relief For Each Child
 
The Coalition's $1 billion family tax package offers two million
families $200 tax relief per child, and single income families - or dual
income families where the full-time child-carer receives "non-work"
dividends, interest and trust income - an extra $500 bonus.



The tax relief package increases the tax-free threshold by $1,000 per
child - saving eligible families $200 a year. The relief applies where
the family income is $70,000 or less ...

articles.title: Child poverty funds pay off
articles.text:
Child poverty funds pay off Child poverty in Australia has fallen by about a third since 1982 on the back of more generous government assistance, according to a paper produced by the National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling (NATSEM).

Using a poverty line set at half the average family income, NATSEM calculated that the child poverty rate has fallen from 18.2 per cent in 1982 to 12.5 per cent in 1995-96. While this means former Prime Minister Mr Bob Hawke fell well short of his pledge t ...

articles.title: Kids Pay Ground
articles.text:
Kids Pay Ground All kinds of child-care arrangements attract government rebates and assistance.

Child-care costs in Sydney range from about $29 a day for family day care schemes ($6,960 for 48 weeks full-time) up to $65 a day for children under two years of age in some long-day-care centres ($15,600 for 48 weeks full-time). Some parents find that their pay is so negligible after subtracting child-care expenses that they opt not to send their children into any care. Others say it is worth the co ...

articles.title: Single-wage families win biggest share of tax breaks.
articles.text:
Single-wage families win biggest share of tax breaks.
 
SINGLE-income families were the big winners in the Budget under the family tax initiative, which provides tax cuts to those earning less than $70,000, amounting to $200 a year for each child and extra tax breaks for those with a spouse at home.



But high-income parents will lose in childcare, with reduced payments for families on more than $70,000 and cuts to operation subsidies which will translate into higher fees.
 
Nursing home resid ...

articles.title: Welfare changes face a fight
articles.text:
Welfare changes face a fight    Budget 2005   

Changes to the welfare system will disadvantage the most disadvantaged, say church groups    CHURCHES have threatened to quit the Government's privatised job network over tough new dole suspension rules, with the Salvation Army saying the changes are not "Christian justice".   

Welfare advocates also have slammed moves to cut the payments for future generations of sole parents and disabled people.   

Under Tuesday's changes, people on the dole wh ...

articles.title: Families in the abuse firing line.
articles.text:
Families in the abuse firing line.
 
ABOUT 400 South Australian children abused in the past 12 months were abused again after their cases were reported to the Family and Youth Affairs Department, it has been revealed.



The problem highlighted the extent of dysfunctional families in the community, particularly single mothers moving from one relationship to another, the Human Services Minister, Mr Brown, said.
 
The Opposition spokeswoman for health, Ms Lea Stevens, yesterday described the stat ...

articles.title: Incentives key to ending poverty traps
articles.text:
Incentives key to ending poverty traps Personal Tax Howard's Tax Blueprint

A major overhaul of the system of family benefits is the centrepiece of the Government's plan to remove welfare poverty traps. From July 1, 2000, the 12 types of family assistance will be merged into three payment schemes with one common means test of 30 per cent.

The threshold income point at which families will begin to lose their family assistance payments will be raised to $28,200 a year for a one-child family.

The ...

articles.title: ADVISERS TO LOOK AT EXPANDING CHILD CARE
articles.text:
ADVISERS TO LOOK AT EXPANDING CHILD CARE
 
CANBERRA: The Federal Government has set up a group of child-care
experts to tell it how to expand child-care services, especially for
sole parents, the unemployed and people living in disadvantaged areas.



The National Children's Services Advisory Council, which will be
announced  today by the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services,
Mr Staples, has been told to look specifically at alternative funding
sources such as employer contributions an ...

articles.title: Children the losers as US cuts its net.
articles.text:
Children the losers as US cuts its net.
 
President Clinton has signed a Bill abolishing guaranteed long-term welfare payments. But, ALEX KOTLOWITZ argues, welfare keeps communities from collapsing A M I missing something?



Throw people off welfare in the name of strengthening families and alleviate poverty? The logic of the Congressional welfare Bill, now an Act, goes something like this: ending a mother's welfare payments will force her to find a job. Bingo. We've got a working mum, and she ...

articles.title: Parents, Disabled On Welfare Hit List
articles.text:
Parents, Disabled On Welfare Hit List
 
Proposals harsh and callous, says ALP



CANBERRA
 
WELFARE cuts aimed at single parents and people on disability support
pensions are expected to form the basis of a radical Federal Government
review.



A discussion paper to be released by Family and Community Services
Minister Jocelyn Newman on Wednesday will contain proposals to stem the
growth in the number of people claiming disability pensions and to
simplify what the Minister sees as an ad hoc sys ...

articles.title: Family tax cuts are for all.
articles.text:
Family tax cuts are for all.
 
THE Federal Government yesterday rejected claims that separated parents would be disadvantaged by the family tax package, worth up to $34 a fortnight from January 1.



Opposition assistant treasury spokesman Mark Latham said about 400,000 parents would miss out because of Australian Taxation Office rules. An accountants' spokesman said parents may have to fill out log books of time they spend with their children.
 
But a spokesman for acting Treasurer John Fahey  ...

articles.title: Berloody Feminists
articles.text:
Berloody Feminists
 
I WAS trying to read a review of a book about the Second World War
when the first paragraph exploded. "There was a time when Australian
men valued virtues such as courage, mateship, stoicism and dependability
in times of crisis  ... these days, feminists have sullied those male
virtues with ridicule and made them vices ... (a time) when men could
still love and sustain each other without feminist scorn." Berloody
feminists. Not content with frightening the horseys, causing  ...

articles.title: JUST THE JOB.
articles.text:
JUST THE JOB.
 
My wife and I both work part-time and have a young son. My wife has lost her job and we need some extra money until she can find something else. She will be claiming Newstart but is there any other payment we could apply for, as things are tough.



A: You may qualify for assistance under the Family Tax Initiative, which provides financial help for low-income and some higher-income families on top of any other assistance they may receive.
 
Lower-income families (less than about ...

articles.title: A Move For The Best
articles.text:
A Move For The Best
 
Housing Minister Brian Howe defends the Federal Government's new
housing package against claims by the Victorian Government that it will
put a heavier burden on the states.



THE MAJOR     reform to housing policy direction announced by the
Prime Minister, Mr Keating, in his Community and Nation statement
addresses the important concerns that have been identified in recent
reports by both the Industry Commission and the National Housing
Strategy.
 
The Prime Minister's st ...

articles.title: Poverty Figure 'wrong'
articles.text:
Poverty Figure 'wrong'
 
CHILD poverty figures released by Mission Australia this week were
highly exaggerated, the WA Council of Social Services has claimed.



Executive director Shawn Boyle said he had access to figures which
showed about 20 per cent of children were affected by child poverty as
opposed to the 40 per cent which Mission Australia released on Monday.
 
But the problem was still a big issue which needed to be addressed
urgently.



Mr Boyle said that in WA alone about 90,000 ch ...

articles.title: Study Finds Two Million In Poverty
articles.text:
Study Finds Two Million In Poverty
 
Canberra  -- Almost two million   or just over one in 10   Australians
could be living in poverty, with sole parents and young people the worst
affected, a new study has found.



But the study also found that the rate of poverty could be almost
halved if the impact of ``social wage'' benefits such as education,
health and housing were added to the traditional income measure.
 
The results of the study, by Professor Ann Harding from the University
of Canberr ...

articles.title: 'ALL TO BENEFIT BUT FAMILIES THE MAJOR WINNERS'
articles.text:
'ALL TO BENEFIT BUT FAMILIES THE MAJOR WINNERS'
 
This is the full text of Mr Howard's overview statement at the launch
of the Liberal tax policy:



The tax reform and reduction program I am announcing today is a
decisive change in the economic direction of Australia.
 
The new deal will help our country, individual Australians, families,
farmers and businesses to get in front again.



The Liberal Party is presenting a clear choice for all Australians on
election day: a choice between the big ...

articles.title: TALL ORDERS, VITAL CHOICES
articles.text:
TALL ORDERS, VITAL CHOICES
 
THE Government is working overtime on "managing" this Budget. It is
already being sold as a balanced package - one that is both tender and
tough. The community is being assured that it will be "sensitive" to the
needs of low-income people, but also one that will not shy away from the
hard decisions required to keep the economy on track.



The ACTU seems convinced. Business has split ranks with more defecting
to the  side of the true believers. But for the Australia ...

articles.title: Welfare's fine until it's reformed
articles.text:
Welfare's fine until it's reformed Everyone agrees with welfare reform until someone tries to reform it. As John Howard is about to discover, it is the detail of welfare reform that gets reforming politicians into trouble.

Jocelyn Newman, the minister in charge of overhauling the welfare system, recently spelled out the principles of reform in a speech to the National Press Club. These included: maintaining equity, simplicity, transparency and sustainability; better incentives to participate in ...

articles.title: Poverty still bottom line for children.
articles.text:
Poverty still bottom line for children.
 
ONE in eight Australian children lives in poverty a decade after former prime minister Bob Hawke vowed to eradicate child poverty.



A study by the National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling at the University of Canberra found almost 13 per cent of dependent children in Australia, about 600,000, below the poverty line.
 
One in four children in poverty was aged under five years and six of every 10 were younger than 10 years of age.



In an elec ...

articles.title: Wooing Women
articles.text:
Wooing Women
 
SARA Dowse, who headed Malcolm Fraser's women's branch from 1975 to
1977, mused on how she and others got child care and women's refuge
funding through a coalition Cabinet.



``We drew on Fraser's ideas about not holding women back, Ayn Rand
type individualism stuff. That enabled us to keep some women's policies
in place, and  Fraser backed us all the way on child care and refuges.
If he hadn't it wouldn't have got through Cabinet. But it had to be a
behind-the-scenes operation: ...

articles.title: 600,000 children still in poverty.
articles.text:
600,000 children still in poverty.
 
NINE years after the date by which no Australian child was to be living in poverty, 600,000 children remain in the ranks of the poor.



The number of children living in poverty in Australia has fallen by a third during the past 17 years, a study has found.
 
But there are still 600,000 living in families on weekly incomes of $365 or less.



This is despite former prime minister Mr Bob Hawke's now-famous election pledge in June, 1987, that "by 1990, no Aust ...

articles.title: WHY MARRIAGE MATTERS / Fault must be found for just family law.
articles.text:
WHY MARRIAGE MATTERS / Fault must be found for just family law.
 
By BARRY MALEY / STURT KRYGSMAN.



Married people enjoy higher levels of wellbeing than the unmarried, as do children living with their two married parents, writes Barry Maley, who says there's an argument for reintroducing fault to divorce
 
SOLE-PARENT families are now linked to a range of social problems. A variety of recent studies shows clear connections between these family circumstances and declining well-being of childre ...

articles.title: Welfare Obligations Must Be A Two-way Street
articles.text:
Welfare Obligations Must Be A Two-way Street Are things right when part-time working mums are made to feel like criminals?

I'D LIKE to introduce you to Holly. She's a part-time secretary in our building, smart, hard-working, and - not that it's relevant - gorgeous. She's also a sole parent of three kids aged 10 to 5. Her husband walked out soon after the youngest was born. Holly gets a part sole parent pension, known as the Parenting Payment Single. Before the recent CPI increase it was worth $ ...

articles.title: By 1996, Fewer Lived In Poverty
articles.text:
By 1996, Fewer Lived In Poverty CANBERRA -- Bob Hawke never delivered on his ambitious promise that no Australian child would live in poverty.

But his government did succeed in cutting child poverty by almost a third, a new study has concluded. The study, by Professor Ann Harding and Ms Aggie Szukalska of the University of Canberra, found that the proportion of Australia's children living in poverty was cut from 18.2 per cent in 1982 to 12.5 per cent in 1995-96, thanks to real increases in soci ...

articles.title: Social Conundrum: Is A Bad Marriage Better Than A Good Divorce?
articles.text:
Social Conundrum: Is A Bad Marriage Better Than A Good Divorce?
 
STAYING together for the sake of the kids. It's such an outdated
notion. What was once seen as an act of sacrifice and moral strength is
today dismissed as misguided masochism. Bitter, tight-lipped martyrs
living in hell with their equally miserable kids. Who needs it?



For the past two or three decades, we've embraced a different approach
to the  issue of children and marriage breakdown. Namely, that divorce
is better for kids ...

articles.title: PLAN TO CAP RENTS BEFORE OLYMPICS
articles.text:
PLAN TO CAP RENTS BEFORE OLYMPICS
 
The State Government will consider organising a residential
landlords'voluntary code to cap pre-Olympics rentals and ensure that
low-income people are not forced out of their homes in the rush for
games profit.



The Minister for Housing, Mr Webster, pledged that the Government
"will ensure that poor people are not disadvantaged by the Olympics".
He promised co-operation with the Federal Housing Minister, Mr Howe, to
achieve this aim.
 
Mr Webster was respon ...

articles.title: Living Standards Of Poorest Children Improve: Research
articles.text:
Living Standards Of Poorest Children Improve: Research
 
The living standards of children from the poorest Australian families
increased sharply154 between 1982 and 1996 because of improvements in
social security payments, research from the University of Canberra has
shown.



The study, by the UC's National Centre for Social and Economic
Modelling, shows the economic well-being of children from families of
all backgrounds - from the poorest to the richest - improved over the
period.
 
The cent ...

articles.title: Parents Become The New Poor - Study
articles.text:
Parents Become The New Poor - Study
 
Canberra  -- The elderly are now less likely to live in poverty than
any other Australians, a new study has found. Instead, almost two-thirds
of Australia's new poor are parents - many of them unemployed.



In a new study Professor Ann Harding, of the University of Canberra,
has identified unemployment, parenthood and broken families as the key
characteristics of people below the poverty line.
 
Yet Professor Harding also found more traditional families am ...

articles.title: Downgrading Child Supports
articles.text:
Downgrading Child Supports
 
THE Federal Government claims, somewhat disingenuously, to have only
the best interests of children at heart in making a series of
questionable changes in child-care funding and child-support provisions.
The outcomes of such changes, however, will in many instances prove not
to be in the best interests of children.



The Government asserts that its reforms will create a fairer
child-care system and that it remains committed to quality child care.
However, $350 mill ...

articles.title: Breadline Tenants `worse Off'
articles.text:
Breadline Tenants `worse Off'
 
Up to 365,000 low-income households would be worse off because of
changes to the Federal Government's rent assistance scheme, the
Australian Council of Social Service said yesterday.



The social welfare body called on the Government to reverse its Budget
decision to raise the level at which people can get rent assistance.
 
Rent assistance is a payment to pensioners and some other groups on
government benefits who rent privately. To get it, tenants must pay a
m ...

articles.title: Letters
articles.text:
Letters Welfare market

In your article on Patrick McClure and his views on corporate welfare (Herald, March 28), Denys Correll was quoted as approvingly referring to the privatisation of community services and the welfare ``marketplace in the 21st century''. It would be hard to imagine a more incongruous analogy than this. It conjures up an image of hordes of eager and willing buyers queuing to buy the new and exciting product called welfare. It also evokes visions of corporately organised ``ch ...

articles.title: The new tax temptations
articles.text:
The new tax temptations Now the battl eover tax reform gets really interesting. This week Kim Beazley outlined a package of big tax cuts he hopes will put great pressure on the Government. Brian Toohey reports.

Suddenly, the tax debate has become a real horse race in which it will no longer be possible to calculate winners and losers merely by looking at rates for income and consumption taxes. Until now, it looked like Labor would go into the election handicapped by its inability to match the C ...

articles.title: EDITORIAL - Working for welfare.
articles.text:
EDITORIAL - Working for welfare.
 
THE view that welfare recipients have an obligation to the community that supports them appeals to taxpayers whose hard work provides the money.



The Howard Government has already introduced a work for the dole scheme.
 
Now a government-commissioned inquiry, in a draft report, has recommended that sole parents and some disabled people get career counselling and other job preparation programs or risk losing benefits.



Family and Community Services Minister ...

articles.title: CHILDCARE SPENDING BOOSTED BY $129M AND FEE RELIEF UP
articles.text:
CHILDCARE SPENDING BOOSTED BY $129M AND FEE RELIEF UP Despite the publication of a 414-page special women's Budget statement, the provision of services for women was not an area which fared particularly well in yesterday's Federal Budget.

But, while few new projects specially targeted women, spending on child care received a boost of $129 million, up 51 per cent on last year. The new child care initiatives focused on making fee relief more equitable, benefiting more lower income families and en ...

articles.title: UNHAPPILY EVER AFTER
articles.text:
UNHAPPILY EVER AFTER
 
Why a bad marriage may be better for your children than a good
divorce.



STAYING together for the sake of the kids. It's such an outdated
notion. What  was once seen as an act of sacrifice and moral strength is
today dismissed as misguided masochism. Bitter tight-lipped martyrs
living in hell with their equally miserable kids. Who needs it?
 
For the past two or three decades, we have embraced a different
approach to the issue of children and marriage breakdown: namely, ...

articles.title: NO FUTURE OR FURNITURE FOR CHILDREN IN PARLIAMENT
articles.text:
NO FUTURE OR FURNITURE FOR CHILDREN IN PARLIAMENT Canberra's building for the 21st century, the new Parliament House, will have an MP's meditation room, four restaurants and a shopping centre, but will not have a child care centre.

A major reason for this is, apparently, that it would create a precedent, with other departments and authorities clamouring to have on-site centres. With the Federal Government's child care policy at a watershed, there are also fears that it would be seen as a politi ...

articles.title: $5.2BN TAX CUTS URGED FOR MIDDLE AUSTRALIA
articles.text:
$5.2BN TAX CUTS URGED FOR MIDDLE AUSTRALIA
 
CANBERRA: The Federal Government's key advisory body on the family has
called for a $29-a-week tax cut - worth $5.2 billion - to compensate
for the rise in middle-income families' tax payments over the past 12
years.



The Federal Government's Australian Institute of Family Studies has
recommended the bold plan to rectify the taxation system's bias against
middle-income families.
 
The institute found that every family (a couple and two children) an ...

articles.title: Teen Mums
articles.text:
Teen Mums
 
Today's teenage mothers are unlikely to fit the traditional stereotype
of the irresponsible drop-out seeking a welfare cheque.  Yet the stigma
surrounding  teenage pregnancy remains well-entrenched.



`PREGNANCY changed my life, but it didn't ruin it, like a lot of
people said it would. It changed it for the better.'' Janelle Voyer's
experience of teenage parenthood is a measure of how the prospects for
young mothers have changed during the past decade or so, as well as of
her own  ...

articles.title: Housing Costs Create Poverty, Report Claims
articles.text:
Housing Costs Create Poverty, Report Claims
 
The high cost of housing is forcing thousands of Australians into
poverty and causing them serious problems in buying food, clothes and
other basic necessities, according to a new report.



The impact of accommodation costs is hardest on elderly single women,
sole parents and couples with two children, according to the report by a
peak housing  group, National Shelter.
 
The report, released yesterday by the Minister for Housing, Mr Howe,
says that ...

articles.title: Housing Sector Gets A Kick-start
articles.text:
Housing Sector Gets A Kick-start
 
Measures to kick-start the housing sector and cut long waiting lists
for public housing were announced in the Budget.



Spending on housing and community amenities leapt by $282.3million, or
20.8 per cent in real terms - one of the biggest increases in the
Budget.
 
About $352.2million of the housing budget will be spent on a two-year
local capital-works program under which grants are provided to local
government for public infrastructure.



Low and moderate ...

articles.title: Children's Need For Protection Clouded By Bureaucracy
articles.text:
Children's Need For Protection Clouded By Bureaucracy
 
CHILD abuse is guaranteed to get a headline these days. It is seen as
one of the greatest, if not the greatest, of our social problems. We
read about horrendous crimes: children strapped into a car that is
pushed into a lake; babies left in a rubbish dumper; toddlers bashed;
childhood that is stolen altogether with sexual ``secrets''. We demand
child protection services.



Every few years we have a scandal. A child dies, or children are
d ...

articles.title: Welfare reform gets diluted as government seeks to fix all problems
articles.text:
Welfare reform gets diluted as government seeks to fix all problems Politicians tend to spread money thinly.

RATHER than limiting the number of problems they know they can afford to tackle, politicians have a tendency to want to give the appearance of fixing every problem they're asked to fix. Take one of the budget's highlights, its measures to raise the workforce participation of welfare recipients. Except for the package to assist the mentally ill, it's hard to think of a worthier cause. It  ...

articles.title: Wealthy will pay more for childcare.
articles.text:
Wealthy will pay more for childcare.
 
FAMILIES across Australia, particularly those in middle-high income brackets, will pay significantly more for childcare under Budget measures announced yesterday by the Howard Government.



In moves designed to target assistance to those in greatest need, all families with incomes over $70,000 a year will now receive a lower level of childcare cash rebate.
 
Also, high-income families with two or more children in care will become ineligible for childcare  ...

articles.title: LOW-INCOME TENANTS TO GET HELP FIRST
articles.text:
LOW-INCOME TENANTS TO GET HELP FIRST
 
The Labor Government has pledged that all low-income households will
be able to afford to rent by 2000, with Government support.



The Minister for Housing, Mr Howe, said that by 2000 Commonwealth
assistance to such households would be paid according to a "benchmark of
affordability" where those paying more than 20 per cent of their income
in rent would be assisted.
 
"As a result, low-income households should not be faced with
unaffordable rents," Mr How ...

articles.title: Rare Disorder Torments Family
articles.text:
Rare Disorder Torments Family
 
I WAS just a child myself 21 years ago. A frightened and confused 16
year old. I thought the toughest experience of  my whole life would be
to give birth to the child I carried at the time. Little did I know what
was in store for me.



Long before my child, Anthony, was born, his father vanished, and to
this date I believe he is unaware of the child's gender and whether I
decided to put him up for adoption.
 
As one so young, I had a formidable task at the time  ...

articles.title: Taking the scalpel to DOCS
articles.text:
Taking the scalpel to DOCS Overloaded on one front, the state's child protection agency fails all, writes Adele Horin.

When the body of a boy was found in a suitcase last year, and a girl was later found starved to death, the State Government could no longer ignore the calls for a major inquiry into the state's child protection system. People wanted answers: why wasn't the Department of Community Services there earlier? How could problems escalate to the point of tragedy?

As evidence unfolded  ...

articles.title: FOOTNOTE
articles.text:
FOOTNOTE Don't blame the welfare state

In his quest for headlines Mark Latham continues to attack the wrong targets. Writing in these pages last week, the Federal Labor MP attacked social security payments when they are clearly not the reason for our stubbornly high level of unemployment. For many years now, recipients of unemployment benefits have been required to actively seek work and take up training opportunities that are available. ACOSS supports a well-balanced policy of mutual obligatio ...

articles.title: Long Road Yet To Travel
articles.text:
Long Road Yet To Travel So-called girl power trivialises hard-won achievements and the century of struggle for women's rights, writes Anne Summers.

WOMEN began this century unable to vote and are finishing it seemingly unable to win. We have, at least in the Western world, achieved legal protections and citizenship entitlements that would have been unthinkable to our great-grandmothers, who could not vote, divorce, or own property (including any money they might have earned from employment) and ...

articles.title: DIVORCE NOT SO BAD FOR CHILDREN.
articles.text:
DIVORCE NOT SO BAD FOR CHILDREN.
 
DIVORCE in itself is not necessarily damaging to children, a report by a research group said yesterday.



The assertion, which flies in the face of accepted wisdom, blames poverty and conflict between parents for the suffering of children from broken homes.
 
Therefore, argues the report, instead of encouraging married couples to stay together, the state should employ specialised social workers to advise them on how best to split amicably and how to start lif ...

articles.title: ONLY HALF AS MANY SOLE PARENTS LIVING IN POVERTY
articles.text:
ONLY HALF AS MANY SOLE PARENTS LIVING IN POVERTY
 
THE number of sole parents living under the poverty line has halved
since 1990 because of a sharp increase in social security payments, a
report has  found.



But the predicament of married couples with or without children has
stagnated or deteriorated during the same period.
 
The director of the national centre for social and economic modelling
at the University of Canberra, Professor Ann Harding, said yesterday
that while the  percentage of ...

articles.title: JUST THEJOB.
articles.text:
JUST THEJOB.
 
My wife and I both work part-time; we have a young son. My wife has just lost her job and we need some extra money until she can find something else. She will claim Newstart, but things are tough - is there any other payment we could apply for?



You may qualify for assistance under the Family Tax Initiative, which provides financial help for low and for some higher-income families on top of any other assistance they may receive.
 
Lower-income families (less than about $27,464  ...

articles.title: HOUSING POLICY DEBATE PROVIDES FIRM GROUNDS FOR IDEOLOGICAL CLASH
articles.text:
HOUSING POLICY DEBATE PROVIDES FIRM GROUNDS FOR IDEOLOGICAL CLASH
 
IT doesn't happen often, but the left-wing of the Federal Government
has put its stamp on an important economic and policy issue in the
Cabinet room.  They have won control of the Federal Government's housing
policy, which in turn  has put the Government on a collision course with
the Liberals in NSW.



Under the Federal Minister for Housing and Aged Care, Mr Staples,
housing policy has been turned on its head.
 
The club with ...

articles.title: Now For The Election
articles.text:
Now For The Election
 
The Howard Government plans to take Australians to an October election
demanding a mandate to introduce massive changes to the nation's
taxation system, including sweeping personal tax cuts and a 10 per cent
GST.



The Prime Minister, Mr John Howard, and the Opposition Leader, Mr Kim
Beazley, vowed that tax would be the election's central battleground
after yesterday's long-awaited unveiling of the coalition's tax reform
package.
 
``It will be no sidebar mandate issue - ...

articles.title: CONFLICT AND POVERTY TAKE HIGHEST TOLL.
articles.text:
CONFLICT AND POVERTY TAKE HIGHEST TOLL.
 
POVERTY and conflict between parents are more to blame for children's suffering than the divorce itself, two Australian researchers have found.



More money should be spent on helping people to split amicably and start a new life than encourage them to stay together, they argue.
 
The report prepared for Britain's influential Joseph Rowntree Foundation claims if parents separated more amicably and without fighting, their children would be as well off a ...

articles.title: STARTING YOUNG
articles.text:
STARTING YOUNG
 
Parents who fear that a child has gone from natural sexual curiosity
to unacceptable behaviour with other children can find that involving
the relevant authorities only makes



things worse.  BETTINA ARNDT reports.
 
CHILDREN are rich sources of social embarrassment, as any parent
knows. But most of us can count ourselves lucky - at least when compared
to Alison, a Sydney woman who, four years ago, found herself mother to
a three-year-old sex molester.



Sex molester? Well, t ...

articles.title: Wade Attacked For Stance On Fining Poorer People
articles.text:
Wade Attacked For Stance On Fining Poorer People
 
Welfare groups have attacked the Victorian Attorney-General, Mrs Wade,
for  refusing to allow low-income people to do community-based work
instead of paying on-the-spot fines.



Unpaid spot fines are dealt with in the Perin Court, which does not
accept instalment payments of less than $10. This may be paid weekly,
fortnightly or monthly, but the registrar, Mr Tony Hargreaves, said
yesterday it was not economic for courts to accept installments ...

articles.title: The new family: Mum works and Dad lives somewhere else
articles.text:
The new family: Mum works and Dad lives somewhere else THE last 10 years have been seen as a decade of conservatism, with a swing back to more traditional values. Students have lost their radicalism, turning from issues such as the redistribution of wealth to gaining economic security

But according to two benchmark studies of the Australian family, the new conservatism may be only skin deep. The actual state of the Australian family has not emerged in the idealised light portrayed in the Libera ...
